nodes.bodyText:
Why? That's not a cleanup from my point of view.
Note, a real cleanup would be to replace the whole if block with
List<Reference> fieldRefs = references.computeIfAbsent(fieldName, k -> new ArrayList<>(1));

This code predates Java 8 so that's why we didn't write it that way at the time. Cleaning this up now with computeIfAbsent makes sense.
Adding redundant parentheses is not a cleanup. Don't do this.
One } too many

This changes the semantics of the method so is not pure cleanup; but it shouldn't be a big risk. However if you do that you should remove the check missingColumns == null which is now useless in one of the caller.
Not sure why you do this, and in pure terms of performance it's an extra useless method call when we're not in debug mode. I wouldn't do this change.
log.debug(e,e) doesn't suit with log4j2 I propose to add a custom message like :  log.debug("createTable error ", e);
What do you mean by "doesn't suit"?
Remove space before final .

launch -> trigger
(also in operation description)

We call them directory entries, not records. record -> entry. exist -> exists
alreadyExist -> alreadyExists
Just call it createBlob
Remove the third argument, UTF-8 is the default.
Why remove the ,? Also in the Javadoc of the new method you keep it.
You should also call this isEmptyDir for consistency
after refactoring finally renamed as "isTableCreated" for consistency
You can use Collections.singletonMap for 1-element maps (in all tests, and in other test classes too).

protected
Initialized with a z, we use American spelling.
Remove commented lines (also in other XML test files).

toLowerCase(Locale.ENGLISH).
Because in the Turkish locale, the lowercase version of I isn't i but ı (dotless i) — and there is an uppercase i with dot: İ

We don't put copyright headers in XML files (especially for tests), it's overkill.

nodes.bodyText: Why not using hasEntry?
Map.of could be better here.
Same for hasEntry
Formatting? . should be aligned afaik.
Could be better to have the full clientSession.newRequest()...execute() to avoid having loadCsv variable.
I think it is done on purpose to avoid auto boxing/unboxing.
sometimes Intellij give bad advise :(

In particular you'll see it a lot in code that I write (also Boolean.valueOf(somebool)) because I have warnings on for autoboxing/autounboxing, due to the fact that autounboxing can lead to NPE (and Eclipse has only one setting for autoboxing/autounboxing...).
Even if it's NEVER_LOAD?

except with config "never" + "never_load", when table is created it is loaded on first init.
Cf. loadingRules
I saw in the table: Never Create + Never Load => no load, that's not the case here for the first init or am I missing something?
if CREATE_TABLE_POLICY_NEVER the boolean isTableCreated is false so if dataLoadingPolicy = "never_load" nothing is loaded
log.debug("Don't load directory: {} on init due to its configuration, dataLoadingPolicy: {} / autoincrement: {}", getName(), dataLoadingPolicy, descriptor.isAutoincrementIdField());

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                        log.debug("calling loadFromCSV with dataLoadingPolicy={} and file name={}", dataLoadingPolicy,
          
          
            
                        log.debug("Load directory: {} with dataLoadingPolicy: {} and file: {}", getName(), dataLoadingPolicy, dataFileName)
These two checks should be after the csvDataFile check in loadFromCSV and should both throw DirectoryException with a bad request.
the public CSVLoaderConsumer() constructor shouldn't be checked ?

Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
                        if (dataLoadingPolicy.equals(ERROR_ON_DUPLICATE)) { // Always this case if table has just been created
          
          
            
                        if (ERROR_ON_DUPLICATE.equals(dataLoadingPolicy)) { // Always this case if table has just been created
I prefer @see at the end, wdyt?

-     * loader.

nodes.bodyText: You're changing the API, please don't or provide backward compatibility.
I don't see anything asserting that we did the job the first time and not the second one, which could be the case here.

when methode is launched thedirectory is initialized with "test-append-directory.csv" wich contains 3 entries.Then we hotrelaod with "test-load-directory.csv" wich contains 2 entries (with one duplicate". Since AutoIncrementId cannot be merge we can see that the size is unchanged (3 entries)
Shouldn't we log the fieldMap to aid debugging?

I put a try/catch/addInfo/re-throw bloc in DirectoryCSV class in order to add as info the line number. We did that to avoid printing in logs sensible data.
While we're doing this change, I saw in DirectoryCSV we're printing csv lines when record is non consistent, I remove this part of log.
I would just do e.addInfo("At line: " + lineno) as the exception message is already in the exception itself.
